tags: at least i know i'm not the only disgusted one
summary: Varys called Daenerys paranoid that she would be betrayed, when in fact she was being betrayed — by Varys.  [...] Worst, Varys...
body:
Varys called Daenerys paranoid that she would be betrayed, when in fact she was being betrayed — by Varys. […] Worst, Varys twice suggested that Jon would be a better ruler exactly because Jon did not want to rule. This is not an original idea: figures ranging from Moses to George Washington to Harry Potter have been exalted in stories because they came to power reluctantly. Those figures also tend to be male. And how do our myths and stories cast women eager for power? As evil queens. And that’s what Daenerys is now: A cliché.

It may be true that power corrupts absolutely. And Game of Thrones may have always wanted to argue that even a heroic figure like Daenerys — a woman we’re set up to root for for seven seasons — can be torn apart by her messiah complex. That’s an interesting idea. Daenerys just needed to evolve to that character over the course of many seasons, in the same way that Sansa evolved from innocent to hardened ruler over many seasons or the Hound softened through his relationship with Arya and other relationships throughout the series.

Instead, Daenerys turned from someone who lived her life by the ethos of justice to someone who burned unarmed men, women and children alive in just a few short episodes. It wasn’t enough.

Eliana Dockterman

It may be true that power corrupts absolutely. And Game of Thrones may have always wanted to argue that even a heroic figure like Daenerys — a woman we’re set up to root for for seven seasons — can be torn apart by her messiah complex. That’s an interesting idea. Daenerys just needed to evolve to that character over the course of many seasons, in the same way that Sansa evolved from innocent to hardened ruler over many seasons or the Hound softened through his relationship with Arya and other relationships throughout the series.

Varys called Daenerys paranoid that she would be betrayed, when in fact she was being betrayed — by Varys. […] Worst, Varys twice suggested that Jon would be a better ruler exactly because Jon did not want to rule. This is not an original idea: figures ranging from Moses to George Washington to Harry Potter have been exalted in stories because they came to power reluctantly. Those figures also tend to be male. And how do our myths and stories cast women eager for power? As evil queens. And that’s what Daenerys is now: A cliché.

It may be true that power corrupts absolutely. And Game of Thrones may have always wanted to argue that even a heroic figure like Daenerys — a woman we’re set up to root for for seven seasons — can be torn apart by her messiah complex. That’s an interesting idea. Daenerys just needed to evolve to that character over the course of many seasons, in the same way that Sansa evolved from innocent to hardened ruler over many seasons or the Hound softened through his relationship with Arya and other relationships throughout the series.

Instead, Daenerys turned from someone who lived her life by the ethos of justice to someone who burned unarmed men, women and children alive in just a few short episodes. It wasn’t enough.

blog.title: Argue just to argue and I'll become dismissive.
blog.description: INTP | Obsessed with Tolkien's world | ASOIAF fan | Anti GOT because I'm over the continuous misogynistic shit from Dumb&Dumber - this is a D&D hate blog | I stan Daenerys Targaryen | VIP Bigbang fan | Blackjack 2NE1 fan | Neverland (G)I-DLE fan | Evillious Chronicles fan | Manwë, Varda, Sauron, Maglor, Lúthien, Shiera Seastar, Alysanne Targaryen, Rhaena Targaryen, and Daenerys Targaryen, and Arianne Martell are my favorite characters | Pro-House Targaryen, deal with it | I ship Manwë/Varda, Finwë/Míriel, Fëanor/Nerdanel, Fingolfin/Anairë, Finarfin/Eärwen, Aldarion/Erendis, Beren/Lúthien, Celegorm/Lúthien, Thingol/Melian, Aragorn/Arwen, Michaela/Clarith, Jaehaerys/Alysanne, Bloodraven/Shiera, Daenerys/Jon | Relationships that interest me the most are Manwë & Melkor, Sauron & Melkor, Melian & Sauron, Sauron & Ar-Pharazôn, Lúthien & Celegorm, Fëanor & Fingolfin & Finarfin, Brynden & Shiera, and Rhaegar Targaryen & Elia Martell | Don't bother arguing with me for the sake of being argumentative because I will become dismissive of you | Header by Yi

summary: Ship that is canon but you don’t ship: 💤
question: Ship that is canon but you don’t ship: 💤
answer: Probably Drogo/Daenerys. Even though I think Drogo genuinely loved her and Dany did feel something towards him, it’s still a severely problematic relationship that should not be romanticized in any way. Daenerys herself seems to be acknowledging that on some level as well, which I’m glad for.

reblog.comment: Probably Drogo/Daenerys. Even though I think Drogo genuinely loved her and Dany did feel something towards him, it’s still a severely problematic relationship that should not be romanticized in any way. Daenerys herself seems to be acknowledging that on some level as well, which I’m glad for.

trail.content_raw: Probably Drogo/Daenerys. Even though I think Drogo genuinely loved her and Dany did feel something towards him, it’s still a severely problematic relationship that should not be romanticized in any way. Daenerys herself seems to be acknowledging that on some level as well, which I’m glad for.
trail.content: Probably Drogo/Daenerys. Even though I think Drogo genuinely loved her and Dany did feel something towards him, it’s still a severely problematic relationship that should not be romanticized in any way. Daenerys herself seems to be acknowledging that on some level as well, which I’m glad for.

tags: you have every right to feel this way
I don't think only dany fans feel this way
this is really what nihilism looks like
summary: Am I wrong to feel like they ruined GOT by ruining Dany? The show looks dead to me and I’m not saying this as a Dany stan. It...
question: Am I wrong to feel like they ruined GOT by ruining Dany? The show looks dead to me and I’m not saying this as a Dany stan. It feels like the show just died.
answer:
History repeats itself. You can’t change it no matter what, no matter how hard you try. Your actions are meaningless. This is the message GOT tells you. And we have to ask ourselves:  so what’s the point of telling a story?

Nothing, and this is why the show feels dead.

reblog.comment:
History repeats itself. You can’t change it no matter what, no matter how hard you try. Your actions are meaningless. This is the message GOT tells you. And we have to ask ourselves:  so what’s the point of telling a story?

Nothing, and this is why the show feels dead.

trail.content_raw:
History repeats itself. You can’t change it no matter what, no matter how hard you try. Your actions are meaningless. This is the message GOT tells you. And we have to ask ourselves:  so what’s the point of telling a story?

Nothing, and this is why the show feels dead.
trail.content:
History repeats itself. You can’t change it no matter what, no matter how hard you try. Your actions are meaningless. This is the message GOT tells you. And we have to ask ourselves:  so what’s the point of telling a story?

Nothing, and this is why the show feels dead.

summary: I guess we all got our bittersweet ending
body:
I guess we all got our bittersweet ending

Bitter = the actual plotlines, character development and literary themes being thrown out the window.

Sweet = how the fandom has largely united against D&D and this season being widely criticised

I like books, art, & coffee. 
I also want to make something very clear. I will not be posting any of my personal politics or beliefs on here. I enjoy tumblr for the books, fandoms, and art.

body:
“Mad Queen” Daenerys

I cried last night. When I watched episode 5 I was just…destroyed. Dany was (and still is. I won’t let S8 destroy her) a very powerful character to me. She used her powers to help others and free slaves. She even befriended and former slave and they were very close to eachother. She avenged her first husband and the child she couldn’t have ever again.

I’ve spent 70 episodes following her story and watching her grow into a powerul queen that is loving and kind; albeit a bit cruel on her enemies, but she never harmed the innocent. She strived to help other. She is Misha, The breaker of chains.

But D&D killed her last episode. And it tore me to pieces. I watched my beloved Khaleesi get butchered, and I think my heart shattered.

D&D might as well have killed her off. It would be better than this BS.

Daenerys, the one we knew, was killed this season, and I mourn her.
